citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
The facility did not use appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat a condition in a Watusi calf. During
inspection the calf was noted to have multiple, small (approximately the size of a quarter), hairless, pale, slightly crusty
lesions on the skin of the face and neck. The facility representative stated that they had already noticed the lesions but
had not taken any steps to prevent, control, diagnose, or treat the condition yet.
Skin conditions causing hair loss in bovine species may be an indicator of trauma or infection. The affected animals may
experience discomfort from the lesions and may be susceptible to spread if treatment is not initiated.
Each dealer or exhibitor shall use the appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat disease and injuries in
accordance with an adequate program of veterinary care, or as directed by the Attending Veterinarian. Correct by
ensuring that the calf be evaluated by the Attending Veterinarian and that an appropriate diagnostic and treatment plan is
implemented and followed. Correct by: November 5, 2024.

An enclosure failed to contain an animal at the facility. During inspection, a juvenile pygmy goat was seen walking in the
yard of the facility outside of its enclosure. The goat was housed in a sheltered housing facility with a pasture attached
and approximately 60 goats housed within. The fencing was a split rail-style fence with small feedlot paneling for sheep
and goats inlaid. It was reported by the facility representative that the juvenile goat, which is smaller than the adults and
most of the other juveniles, exited the enclosure by squeezing between the gate and a post. The facility representative
reports the goat goes in and out on its own volition all day. Enclosures that do not properly contain animals pose a risk of
injury to or loss of the animals. Correct by ensuring the facility's enclosures be constructed of such material appropriate
for the species housed within, in order to protect the animals from injury, and contain the animals.

There is no perimeter fence around an enclosure housing 4 kangaroos that can restrict animals or unauthorized persons
from going through it or under it. A perimeter fence protects animals from contact with unauthorized persons and animals.
A perimeter fence also acts as a secondary containment system if an animal escapes from its primary enclosure. All
outdoor housing facilities must be enclosed by a perimeter fence that is of sufficient height to keep animals and
unauthorized person out. Fences less than 8 feet high for potentially dangerous animals, such as but not limited to, large
felines (e.g., lions, tigers, leopards, cougars, etc.), bears, wolves, rhinoceros, and elephants, or less than 6 feet high for
other animals must be approved in writing by the Administrator. The fence must be constructed so that it protects the
animals in the facility by restricting animals and unauthorized persons from going through it or under it and having contact
with the animals in the facility, and so that it can function as a secondary containment system for the animals in the
facility. It must be of sufficient distance from the outside of the primary enclosure to prevent physical contact between
animals inside the enclosure and animals or persons outside the perimeter fence. Such fences less than 3 feet in distance
from the primary enclosure must be approved in writing by the Administrator. Correct by ensuring that all species requiring
a perimeter fence are completely enclosed within an adequate perimeter fence that meets all requirements. Alternatively,
a variance may be requested in writing and sent to the APHIS Administrator.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative.
Additional Inspectors:
Eric Irvin, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
The facility did not use appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat a condition in a Watusi calf. During

Skin conditions causing hair loss in bovine species may be an indicator of trauma or infection. The affected animals may 
experience discomfort from the lesions and may be susceptible to spread if treatment is not initiated.  
 
Each dealer or exhibitor shall use the appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat disease and injuries in

ensuring that the calf be evaluated by the Attending Veterinarian and that an appropriate diagnostic and treatment plan is

3.125(a)  Repeat
   
Facilities, general. 
An enclosure failed to contain an animal at the facility. During inspection, a juvenile pygmy goat was seen walking in the

for the species housed within, in order to protect the animals from injury, and contain the animals. 
3.127(d)  Repeat
   
Facilities, outdoor.

There is no perimeter fence around an enclosure housing 4 kangaroos that can restrict animals or unauthorized persons 
from going through it or under it. A perimeter fence protects animals from contact with unauthorized persons and animals. 
A perimeter fence also acts as a secondary containment system if an animal escapes from its primary enclosure. All

from the primary enclosure must be approved in writing by the Administrator. Correct by ensuring that all species requiring

This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
Eric Irvin, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

species.common: DOMESTIC PIG / POTBELLY PIG / MICRO PIG
